comments:
I20040428

Steps to reproduce:
1. Start a workbench with I20040428
2. Exit
3. Patch with latest org.eclipse.jdt.core
4. Restart

If you look at the code you will see that the NPE just cannot happen.

Deleting the config dir makes things work.

I suspect you did not get fully off the compatibility layer.  The fact that 
PluginActivator is on the stack indicates that the runtime still thinks you 
need compatibility treatment.  Check your plugin.xml and ensure that the 
dependency on runtime.compatibility has been changed to just runtime.  

If you are changing an existing install by overwriting a new plugin.xml or some 
such, ensure that you run with -dev or -Dosgi.checkConfiguration=true (VM arg) 
after changing the plugin.xml.

My plugin.xml has no dependency on runtime.compatibility. However I did not run 
with the flags you indicated after I patched my Eclipse install. I didn't 
expect to have to use any magic as I patch org.eclipse.jdt.core on a regular 
basis. 

So it looks like some information is cached in the config dir and to force this 
information to be recomputed, I need to use -dev or -
Dosgi.checkConfiguration=true. Right?

you don't have to do this on a regular basis, just if you go and change things 
without telling Eclipse.  The scenario where someone tweaks an installed plugin 
is very rare in the grand scheme of things.  Its is rare in development 
scenarios and NEVER happens in product scenarios.  It is actually quite costly 
for the runtime to go around checking all the timestamps etc to ensure that the 
user has not changed something so we turn that off by default.
*** Bug 60548 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***

OK, thanks for the info. Is Update prepared for this kind of scenario ? (I'm 
thinking of people trying to patch I20040428 with org.eclipse.jdt.core 
Cheetah05 that is being prepared)

Cheetah is installed as a patch using the Update mechanism.  Yes that works (at 
least it does now).  If people install cheetah by unzipping a new JDTcore 
plugin *content* over the previous one then they will have to use the triggers 
listed here to find the new content.  If they install the patch as a new plugin 
then update should find it.
